this is a course about meaning
the idea is to understand first what the
standard model is for understanding how
it is that we can use language to
communicate to transfer information
between us
the second part of the course
is to understand why vagueness spells
disaster for the standard model
sometimes when people teach a graduate
course on vagueness they do so in a very
puzzle oriented way this is not how I
teach the course I think of it as a big
picture course in the philosophy of
language the idea is to use vagueness to
understand how meaning works
affairs something one might call the
standard model
a picture whereby sentences have
meanings and we can use these meanings
in etherea communication to explain how
it is that language works
the way I see vagueness it
draws the standard model
so I think of the course as an effort to
First understand why the standard model
is threatened by vagueness and secondly
to try and find an alternate model that
can explain how communication Works in
spite of fakeness
a typical class session will consist of
overall discussion
amongst everyone in the seminar so there
is very little lecture what happens is
we've all read a text
and
I might say a few words to get the
discussion warmed up and after that
people bring up problems we discuss the
problems and it's in these interactions
that we acquire an understanding of
what's going on
in teaching a course about vagueness one
faces a challenge because the literature
is enormous
so one has to either
discuss many texts and not too much
detail or discuss a few in a lot of
detail and I choose the latter approach
so
I've picked maybe 10 or 12 texts which I
think are especially illuminated and we
spent a lot of time getting to
understand each of them really well
I think this would be a difficult course
to take on one's own
uh if someone wanted to take it from a
distance what I would recommend is
finding a partner finding someone to do
the readings with and discuss them
I want to ask someone to talk these
things through with it makes a big
difference because the issues are subtle
and it's often difficult to identify
them on a first reading
